title: How to Bring Out Red Tones in Hair

steps.headline: Start with clean, dry hair.
steps.description: If your hair contains any products like gels, hair sprays, or leave-in conditioners, you will need to wash them out first. It is also a good idea to wash your hair if you haven't in several days. Shampoo your hair as you normally would. Do not apply a conditioner. Let your hair air dry completely before moving on to the next step. After washing your hair, put on an old t-shirt that you don't mind getting stained.

steps.headline: Boil two cups of water.
steps.description: Pour two cups (473 ml) of water into a pot. Place your pot on the stove. Set the heat to medium high. Once your water starts to boil, in about eight to ten minutes, turn off the heat.

steps.headline: Add three to five hibiscus tea bags to the boiling water.
steps.description: Steep the tea bags for five to ten minutes. The longer you steep the tea, the stronger the color will be. Alternatively, steep one cup (237 ml) of dried hibiscus flowers. Use natural or organic tea that contains only hibiscus, or lists hibiscus as the first ingredient. Ideally, you want hibiscus to be the only ingredient. Also avoid using hibiscus tea mixes like green tea hibiscus. Instead, use pure, herbal hibiscus teas.

steps.headline: Cool the tea to room temperature.
steps.description: After the tea has finished steeping, let it cool to room temperature, about five to eight minutes. Pour the cooled tea into a spray bottle.

steps.headline: Divide your hair into three sections.
steps.description: Using a comb, divide your hair into a top, middle, and bottom section. The top section should include the hair that lies above your temples. The middle section should include the hair below your temples to the middle of your ear, and the bottom section should include everything else. Since you will be starting with the bottom section, leave the hair in this section down. Use hair clips to hold up the middle and bottom sections of hair.

steps.headline: Spray your hair with the tea.
steps.description: Hold the spray bottle three to four inches away from your hair. Starting with the bottom section, generously spray your hair with the tea. Your hair should be slightly wet at this point. Comb through your hair to disperse the tea evenly. Repeat this process for the middle and top sections.

steps.headline: Let your hair set for one hour.
steps.description: If you want a richer color, then let it set for two hours. To speed up the highlighting process, blow dry your hair or sit outside in the sun while the tea is still in your hair.

steps.headline: Shampoo and condition your hair.
steps.description: After your hair has finished setting, shampoo your hair as you normally would. Apply a conditioner as well. Then rinse and dry your hair.

steps.headline: Start with clean, dry hair.
steps.description: Do not apply a conditioner. Let your hair air dry. Make sure your hair is completely dry before adding the carrot juice. After you wash your hair, put on an old t-shirt that you do not mind getting stained.

steps.headline: Juice three to four medium sized carrots.
steps.description: Wash and peel the carrots. Place the carrots in a juicer. You will need ½ cup (118 ml) of carrot juice. For a deeper red, add ½ cup (118 ml) of beet juice, about two to three beets, to the carrot juice. You can also use pure beet juice to color your hair instead of a carrot-beet mixture.

steps.headline: Add yogurt and honey to the juice.
steps.description: Add 3 tablespoons (44 ml) of yogurt to the juice. Then add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of honey. Mix the juice, yogurt and honey together until a paste forms.

steps.headline: Divide your hair into three sections.
steps.description: Use a comb to divide your hair into a top, middle, and bottom section. Since you will be starting with the bottom section, leave the hair in this section down. Use hair clips to hold up the middle and top sections of hair. The top section should include the hair that lies above your temples. The middle section should include the hair below your temples to the middle of your ear, and the bottom section should include everything else.

steps.headline: Apply the mix to your hair.
steps.description: Starting with the bottom section, apply a generous amount of paste from the roots to the ends of your hair. Comb through your hair to disperse the paste evenly. Repeat this process for each section. To protect your hands, wear rubber gloves.

steps.headline: Let your hair set for one hour.
steps.description: After one hour, rinse your hair. Avoid shampooing your hair since this may wash out the color. To help the staying power of the color, apply a leave-in conditioner.

steps.headline: Purchase a natural or organic henna hair dye.
steps.description:
You can find natural henna hair dyes at your local health food store, beauty supply store, or online. The ingredients list should read, “100% henna.”
Henna is a very popular method for coloring hair.

steps.headline: Start with clean hair.
steps.description: Shampoo your hair as you normally would. Do not apply a conditioner. Let your hair air dry. Make sure your hair is completely dry before proceeding.

steps.headline: Place newspapers on your bathroom floor.
steps.description: The newspapers will protect your floor if you accidentally spill some henna. Also place three to four old or dark-colored hand towels nearby. Use these to wipe away any spilled henna on your skin or sink. Alternatively, you can use a drop cloth to protect your bathroom floor.

steps.headline: Cover your hairline with a protective balm.
steps.description: Use a non-petroleum jelly, like coconut oil, or another type of balm. Apply a generous amount of balm along your hairline and around your ears. This way you can avoid staining your skin.

steps.headline: Wear an old t-shirt.
steps.description: The t-shirt will protect your shoulders, upper arms, and back from getting stained. To protect your neck, place a dark-colored towel around your neck. Also put on a pair of nylon gloves to protect your hands. Make sure it is a t-shirt that you don't mind getting stained.

steps.headline: Divide your hair into three sections.
steps.description: Using a comb, divide your hair into a top, middle, and bottom section. Leave the hair in the bottom section down since you will be starting with this section Use hair clips to hold up the middle and top sections of hair. The top section should include the hair that lies above your temples. The middle section should include the hair below your temples to the middle of your ear, and the bottom section should include everything else.

steps.headline: Prepare the henna per the instructions on the package.
steps.description: Some henna comes in a powdered form where you are required to mix it with hot water. Others come in a solid form where you are required to melt it using hot water.

steps.headline: Apply the henna one section at a time.
steps.description: Starting with the bottom section of hair, use your hands to work the henna from the roots down to the tips of your hair. Additionally, start from the back of your hair and move forward. Because henna is thick, massage the henna into your hair for the best results. Repeat this process for each section.

steps.headline: Let your hair set for the recommended amount of time.
steps.description: Clip up your hair and let it set per the instructions on the package. Typically, you will need to let your hair set for at least one hour. Once you've applied the henna to your hair, cover it with a plastic shower cap. The shower cap will seal in your head's natural heat, helping the henna soak into your hair.

steps.headline: Shampoo and condition your hair.
steps.description: After your hair has finished setting, wash it with shampoo. Wash your hair thoroughly until all of the henna is removed. Apply a conditioner as well. The color will keep developing for 24 to 48 hours.

text:
Using Hibiscus Tea Start with clean, dry hair. If your hair contains any products like gels, hair sprays, or leave-in conditioners, you will need to wash them out first. It is also a good idea to wash your hair if you haven't in several days. Shampoo your hair as you normally would. Do not apply a conditioner. Let your hair air dry completely before moving on to the next step. After washing your hair, put on an old t-shirt that you don't mind getting stained. Boil two cups of water. Pour two cups (473 ml) of water into a pot. Place your pot on the stove. Set the heat to medium high. Once your water starts to boil, in about eight to ten minutes, turn off the heat. Add three to five hibiscus tea bags to the boiling water. Steep the tea bags for five to ten minutes. The longer you steep the tea, the stronger the color will be. Alternatively, steep one cup (237 ml) of dried hibiscus flowers. Use natural or organic tea that contains only hibiscus, or lists hibiscus as the first ingredient. Ideally, you want hibiscus to be the only ingredient. Also avoid using hibiscus tea mixes like green tea hibiscus. Instead, use pure, herbal hibiscus teas. Cool the tea to room temperature. After the tea has finished steeping, let it cool to room temperature, about five to eight minutes. Pour the cooled tea into a spray bottle. Divide your hair into three sections. Using a comb, divide your hair into a top, middle, and bottom section. The top section should include the hair that lies above your temples. The middle section should include the hair below your temples to the middle of your ear, and the bottom section should include everything else. Since you will be starting with the bottom section, leave the hair in this section down. Use hair clips to hold up the middle and bottom sections of hair. Spray your hair with the tea. Hold the spray bottle three to four inches away from your hair. Starting with the bottom section, generously spray your hair with the tea. Your hair should be slightly wet at this point. Comb through your hair to disperse the tea evenly. Repeat this process for the middle and top sections. Let your hair set for one hour. If you want a richer color, then let it set for two hours. To speed up the highlighting process, blow dry your hair or sit outside in the sun while the tea is still in your hair. Shampoo and condition your hair. After your hair has finished setting, shampoo your hair as you normally would. Apply a conditioner as well. Then rinse and dry your hair. Trying Carrot Juice Start with clean, dry hair. Do not apply a conditioner. Let your hair air dry. Make sure your hair is completely dry before adding the carrot juice. After you wash your hair, put on an old t-shirt that you do not mind getting stained. Juice three to four medium sized carrots. Wash and peel the carrots. Place the carrots in a juicer. You will need ½ cup (118 ml) of carrot juice. For a deeper red, add ½ cup (118 ml) of beet juice, about two to three beets, to the carrot juice. You can also use pure beet juice to color your hair instead of a carrot-beet mixture. Add yogurt and honey to the juice. Add 3 tablespoons (44 ml) of yogurt to the juice. Then add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of honey. Mix the juice, yogurt and honey together until a paste forms. Divide your hair into three sections. Use a comb to divide your hair into a top, middle, and bottom section. Since you will be starting with the bottom section, leave the hair in this section down. Use hair clips to hold up the middle and top sections of hair. The top section should include the hair that lies above your temples. The middle section should include the hair below your temples to the middle of your ear, and the bottom section should include everything else. Apply the mix to your hair. Starting with the bottom section, apply a generous amount of paste from the roots to the ends of your hair. Comb through your hair to disperse the paste evenly. Repeat this process for each section. To protect your hands, wear rubber gloves. Let your hair set for one hour. After one hour, rinse your hair. Avoid shampooing your hair since this may wash out the color. To help the staying power of the color, apply a leave-in conditioner. Using Henna Purchase a natural or organic henna hair dye. You can find natural henna hair dyes at your local health food store, beauty supply store, or online. The ingredients list should read, “100% henna.”
Henna is a very popular method for coloring hair. Start with clean hair. Shampoo your hair as you normally would. Do not apply a conditioner. Let your hair air dry. Make sure your hair is completely dry before proceeding. Place newspapers on your bathroom floor. The newspapers will protect your floor if you accidentally spill some henna. Also place three to four old or dark-colored hand towels nearby. Use these to wipe away any spilled henna on your skin or sink. Alternatively, you can use a drop cloth to protect your bathroom floor. Cover your hairline with a protective balm. Use a non-petroleum jelly, like coconut oil, or another type of balm. Apply a generous amount of balm along your hairline and around your ears. This way you can avoid staining your skin. Wear an old t-shirt. The t-shirt will protect your shoulders, upper arms, and back from getting stained. To protect your neck, place a dark-colored towel around your neck. Also put on a pair of nylon gloves to protect your hands. Make sure it is a t-shirt that you don't mind getting stained. Divide your hair into three sections. Using a comb, divide your hair into a top, middle, and bottom section. Leave the hair in the bottom section down since you will be starting with this section Use hair clips to hold up the middle and top sections of hair. The top section should include the hair that lies above your temples. The middle section should include the hair below your temples to the middle of your ear, and the bottom section should include everything else. Prepare the henna per the instructions on the package. Some henna comes in a powdered form where you are required to mix it with hot water. Others come in a solid form where you are required to melt it using hot water. Apply the henna one section at a time. Starting with the bottom section of hair, use your hands to work the henna from the roots down to the tips of your hair. Additionally, start from the back of your hair and move forward. Because henna is thick, massage the henna into your hair for the best results. Repeat this process for each section. Let your hair set for the recommended amount of time. Clip up your hair and let it set per the instructions on the package. Typically, you will need to let your hair set for at least one hour. Once you've applied the henna to your hair, cover it with a plastic shower cap. The shower cap will seal in your head's natural heat, helping the henna soak into your hair. Shampoo and condition your hair. After your hair has finished setting, wash it with shampoo. Wash your hair thoroughly until all of the henna is removed. Apply a conditioner as well. The color will keep developing for 24 to 48 hours.
sentences: Using Hibiscus Tea Start with clean, dry hair.
If your hair contains any products like gels, hair sprays, or leave-in conditioners, you will need to wash them out first.
It is also a good idea to wash your hair if you haven't in several days.
Shampoo your hair as you normally would.
Do not apply a conditioner.
Let your hair air dry completely before moving on to the next step.
After washing your hair, put on an old t-shirt that you don't mind getting stained.
Boil two cups of water.
Pour two cups (473 ml) of water into a pot.
Place your pot on the stove.
Set the heat to medium high.
Once your water starts to boil, in about eight to ten minutes, turn off the heat.
Add three to five hibiscus tea bags to the boiling water.
Steep the tea bags for five to ten minutes.
The longer you steep the tea, the stronger the color will be.
Alternatively, steep one cup (237 ml) of dried hibiscus flowers.
Use natural or organic tea that contains only hibiscus, or lists hibiscus as the first ingredient.
Ideally, you want hibiscus to be the only ingredient.
Also avoid using hibiscus tea mixes like green tea hibiscus.
Instead, use pure, herbal hibiscus teas.
Cool the tea to room temperature.
After the tea has finished steeping, let it cool to room temperature, about five to eight minutes.
Pour the cooled tea into a spray bottle.
Divide your hair into three sections.
Using a comb, divide your hair into a top, middle, and bottom section.
The top section should include the hair that lies above your temples.
The middle section should include the hair below your temples to the middle of your ear, and the bottom section should include everything else.
Since you will be starting with the bottom section, leave the hair in this section down.
Use hair clips to hold up the middle and bottom sections of hair.
Spray your hair with the tea.
Hold the spray bottle three to four inches away from your hair.
Starting with the bottom section, generously spray your hair with the tea.
Your hair should be slightly wet at this point.
Comb through your hair to disperse the tea evenly.
Repeat this process for the middle and top sections.
Let your hair set for one hour.
If you want a richer color, then let it set for two hours.
To speed up the highlighting process, blow dry your hair or sit outside in the sun while the tea is still in your hair.
Shampoo and condition your hair.
After your hair has finished setting, shampoo your hair as you normally would.
Apply a conditioner as well.
Then rinse and dry your hair.
Trying Carrot Juice Start with clean, dry hair.
Do not apply a conditioner.
Let your hair air dry.
Make sure your hair is completely dry before adding the carrot juice.
After you wash your hair, put on an old t-shirt that you do not mind getting stained.
Juice three to four medium sized carrots.
Wash and peel the carrots.
Place the carrots in a juicer.
You will need ½ cup (118 ml) of carrot juice.
For a deeper red, add ½ cup (118 ml) of beet juice, about two to three beets, to the carrot juice.
You can also use pure beet juice to color your hair instead of a carrot-beet mixture.
Add yogurt and honey to the juice.
Add 3 tablespoons (44 ml) of yogurt to the juice.
Then add 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of honey.
Mix the juice, yogurt and honey together until a paste forms.
Divide your hair into three sections.
Use a comb to divide your hair into a top, middle, and bottom section.
Since you will be starting with the bottom section, leave the hair in this section down.
Use hair clips to hold up the middle and top sections of hair.
The top section should include the hair that lies above your temples.
The middle section should include the hair below your temples to the middle of your ear, and the bottom section should include everything else.
Apply the mix to your hair.
Starting with the bottom section, apply a generous amount of paste from the roots to the ends of your hair.
Comb through your hair to disperse the paste evenly.
Repeat this process for each section.
To protect your hands, wear rubber gloves.
Let your hair set for one hour.
After one hour, rinse your hair.
Avoid shampooing your hair since this may wash out the color.
To help the staying power of the color, apply a leave-in conditioner.
Using Henna Purchase a natural or organic henna hair dye.
You can find natural henna hair dyes at your local health food store, beauty supply store, or online.

The ingredients list should read, “100% henna.”
Henna is a very popular method for coloring hair.
Start with clean hair.
Shampoo your hair as you normally would.
Do not apply a conditioner.
Let your hair air dry.
Make sure your hair is completely dry before proceeding.
Place newspapers on your bathroom floor.
The newspapers will protect your floor if you accidentally spill some henna.
Also place three to four old or dark-colored hand towels nearby.
Use these to wipe away any spilled henna on your skin or sink.
Alternatively, you can use a drop cloth to protect your bathroom floor.
Cover your hairline with a protective balm.
Use a non-petroleum jelly, like coconut oil, or another type of balm.
Apply a generous amount of balm along your hairline and around your ears.
This way you can avoid staining your skin.
Wear an old t-shirt.
The t-shirt will protect your shoulders, upper arms, and back from getting stained.
To protect your neck, place a dark-colored towel around your neck.
Also put on a pair of nylon gloves to protect your hands.
Make sure it is a t-shirt that you don't mind getting stained.
Divide your hair into three sections.
Using a comb, divide your hair into a top, middle, and bottom section.
Leave the hair in the bottom section down since you will be starting with this section Use hair clips to hold up the middle and top sections of hair.
The top section should include the hair that lies above your temples.
The middle section should include the hair below your temples to the middle of your ear, and the bottom section should include everything else.
Prepare the henna per the instructions on the package.
Some henna comes in a powdered form where you are required to mix it with hot water.
Others come in a solid form where you are required to melt it using hot water.
Apply the henna one section at a time.
Starting with the bottom section of hair, use your hands to work the henna from the roots down to the tips of your hair.
Additionally, start from the back of your hair and move forward.
Because henna is thick, massage the henna into your hair for the best results.
Repeat this process for each section.
Let your hair set for the recommended amount of time.
Clip up your hair and let it set per the instructions on the package.
Typically, you will need to let your hair set for at least one hour.
Once you've applied the henna to your hair, cover it with a plastic shower cap.
The shower cap will seal in your head's natural heat, helping the henna soak into your hair.
Shampoo and condition your hair.
After your hair has finished setting, wash it with shampoo.
Wash your hair thoroughly until all of the henna is removed.
Apply a conditioner as well.
The color will keep developing for 24 to 48 hours.
